results.content: Pace is too fast. This is especially true of the coding, which flies across the screen as if it's pre-recorded.
results.content_html: Pace is too fast. This is especially true of the coding, which flies across the screen as if it's pre-recorded.

results.content: too fast and with many things to know upfront and the audio is also very poor. Seems to dump tons of code too quickly rather than clearly focus on concepts
results.content_html: too fast and with many things to know upfront and the audio is also very poor. Seems to dump tons of code too quickly rather than clearly focus on concepts

results.content:
Excellent course and interesting examples that are enhanced as the lectures progress. Very quick pace - definitely suggest a good JS background (for code structuring and closures) and great discussion of functional programming and good reusable patterns for development.

It'd be great if there was a little more explanation of some of the d3 api functionality regarding the currying and and bin operations. A bit of familiarity with d3 is helpful going into the material (which is inferred by the title). Really well organized and super useful takeaways. Note though, you do need to pause and digest the material :)
results.content_html:

results.content: The instructor is clearly an expert in the subject but it is very difficult to follow because of poor delivery and seems to dump tons of code too quickly rather than clearly focus on concepts
results.content_html: The instructor is clearly an expert in the subject but it is very difficult to follow because of poor delivery and seems to dump tons of code too quickly rather than clearly focus on concepts

results.content:
In this video course the author develops a complex software project, dividing it into simpler parts each of which relates to a certain aspect of D3 (layouts, data manipulation, animation, interactivity,...).
The explanation given of each part is comprehensive and the teacher shows to be very confident and competent, offering useful indications for both the D3 library and javascript in general.
I really appreciated the fact that the author gives (during the exposition) useful tips on how to deal with commons problems. Also there’s chapters dedicated to important topics such as how to get external libraries, how to debug the javascript code and some best practices. The last chapter is inspiring: it’s about how to approach properly data visualization and how to realize effective charts.
There’s only two things I don’t like so much: 1) advanced concepts  (like functional programming and GIS) are used in the examples. Many students may not be able to understand them. 2) The teacher speaks and writes code rather quickly and it’s often difficult to understand what he is doing without viewing the video a second time.
results.content_html:
In this video course the author develops a complex software project, dividing it into simpler parts each of which relates to a certain aspect of D3 (layouts, data manipulation, animation, interactivity,...).
The explanation given of each part is comprehensive and the teacher shows to be very confident and competent, offering useful indications for both the D3 library and javascript in general.
I really appreciated the fact that the author gives (during the exposition) useful tips on how to deal with commons problems. Also there’s chapters dedicated to important topics such as how to get external libraries, how to debug the javascript code and some best practices. The last chapter is inspiring: it’s about how to approach properly data visualization and how to realize effective charts.
There’s only two things I don’t like so much: 1) advanced concepts (like functional programming and GIS) are used in the examples. Many students may not be able to understand them. 2) The teacher speaks and writes code rather quickly and it’s often difficult to understand what he is doing without viewing the video a second time.

results.content: Very enlightening, for a deeper use of D3.js In addition, I found the section on obtaining raw data and making it workable very useful.
results.content_html: Very enlightening, for a deeper use of D3.js In addition, I found the section on obtaining raw data and making it workable very useful.

results.content: I am following along but I feel some details on layouts are missing...but I will see.
results.content_html: I am following along but I feel some details on layouts are missing...but I will see.

results.content:
Swizec goes through concepts pretty quick and engages people who are watching it. I particularly liked that the author discussed libraries such as lo-dash (data manipulation), underscore.js, c3.js, etc... The author's accent takes time to get use to but it is totally worth it because the author manages to cover many things in short period of time.

This is not a "d3.js-from-scratch" course, you should already be proficient in HTML, CSS and JavaScript. Do read up little on d3.js from the website and keep the API reference link (http://devdocs.io/d3/) open in your browser. Also get the book if possible.
